+Cherry Olive No Cherry Olive, I am actually South African. Your statement 
is as contradictory as it is prejudicial, because my nationality (or skin 
colour for that matter) has absolutely no relevance or bearing whatsoever 
on my capacity to understand and comprehend English. 

Your statements are an ABSOLUTE DISGRACE to our nation, Cherry Olive. 
Sadly, comments like yours are spawned from the very same "shithole" 
mentality which you sweepingly attribute to a country with nearly 52 
MILLION PEOPLE.  

When you say that "black people [are] taking over and ruining everything we 
brought to them", are you including ALL BLACK PEOPLE in that statement? Or 
are you actually referring to individuals within the present presidential 
regime?

Does your statement include "black people" like Nelson Mandela?

For that matter, who is "WE", Cherry Olive? Does that statement refer to 
ALL WHITE PEOPLE? Or just a few? Are you ONE of those few? WHAT ARE YOU 
CONTRIBUTING to the very "black people" that you are accusing?       

As for your claim that my comments are "besides the point", the actual 
truth might surprise you. Research has clearly demonstrated time and time 
again (both locally and abroad) that declining levels of education have 
been closely linked to escalating levels of violence. Below is an example 
of one such study. Would you like me to quote a few more studies for you, 
Cherry Olive?

http://ftp.iza.org/dp5000.pdf
    
Perhaps you have NO RESPECT for such studies, in which case I would implore 
you to use some good old fashioned "COMMON SENSE". Now then, an individual 
with a POOR level of education has FEWER EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES, and is 
therefore more likely to consider crime. Do you doubt this? 

The ability to understand English, Cherry Olive, is as important to basic 
human-to-human communication as it is to enhancing employment 
opportunities. If an individual cannot express themselves adequately, they 
are also more likely to develop feelings of anger and frustration - which 
can also lead to VIOLENT BEHAVIOUR. Do you doubt this?  

In light of these studies, and contrary to your unsubstantiated 
accusations, I believe that my comments ARE ACTUALLY MORE "TO THE POINT" 
THAN PEOPLE LIKE YOU REALIZE!

Of course, the level of education is not the ONLY reason for escalating 
crime and violence, but it certainly is an instigator worth considering, 
don't you think?

I don't suppose you actually considered ANY OF THIS, did you? Of course 
not.  

Perhaps if these hijackers had higher levels of education, their minds 
might just be made fertile enough to consider alternative "career paths" in 
opposed to hijacking people and "doing crime", don't you think?

Here's the thing, Cherry Olive... CHANGE HAPPENS ON AN INDIVIDUAL LEVEL 
FIRST...so when I correct someone else's blatantly poor level of English 
comprehension, I am actually CONTRIBUTING to education in a positive way 
because of the influence and ubiquity of social media. Do you THINK OF 
THAT? Of course you didn't.

A WORD OF WARNING, Cherry Olive. Your disgusting statements are now on 
PUBLIC RECORD, so in future THINK TWICE before committing your BRAIN-FART 
comments to digital paper.

If you choose not to heed this warning, I will not hesitate to further 
debunk your idiotic and inane comments.

+Gerald Lim KC Clearly, the level of English education and comprehension is 
declining.

This is true, but the way our structure is at the moment it wont happen 
like we all want for a very long while. If we could runa petition to get 
rid of all the monopoly in this regard it would relieve all these problems. 
Thats a lot to be paying for 4 bonded lines. from who. well once fiber is 
eventually integrated the more people that use it the more the price will 
go down we HOPE..............

that's per 1, with a connection that offers a much lower ping than our 
current connections. Imagine they decided to allow it to all south africans 
on there, work it out like this, how many people do u know that uses the 
internet in SA? There's no downtime, no cable theft, nothing like that, all 
of it is already up and running and waiting for everyone, and they come up 
to a group in say joburg, and say Pay us R8000 and we'll give you 10mbps up 
and down with a contenation ratio of 10:1 instead of 48:1 like our adsl, 
which means a latency average of about 80MS to America, maybe even less, 
I'm pretty sure I'd choose that over the current implementation where we 
have 4 Bonded lines and we're paying R10 000 a month but havent even got 
the full 16mbps, or the full 2mbps upload to go with it. we're getting an 
average 11 mbps and 1.5mbps upload, my point friend, is that it's much 
better than telkom. and if you take about 1/2 of all the people on telkoms 
network like that you'd be pretty keen on dropping ur prices to get the 
other half to come over.

Yea, sounds like icasa. http://www.attwb.net/ You stated AT&T's satellite 
internet would be cheaper. its more expensive.

AT&T LEO (low earth Orbit) satellites are already above south africa, they 
operate on a frequency that ICASA banned bro, so all of it is already here, 
but our lovely country would rather struggle than have things done 
properly, telkom and icasa are bunched up together like a bunch of 
criminals on their own.

Yes i know we would need azure servers, lets just face it we need azure 
servers full stop not just to implement this. Also What i find pathetic is 
why eskom HAS to be the sole provider of electricity, we need Independant 
providers of electrictiy in this country as well as other things. The 
camera wouldnt be too much of an issue if someone could start this out then 
that person would have to procure those cameras. 

Agreed that fibre will take a little while before it becomes in the 
acceptable price range, Umhlaga Rocks in Durban you can get 100mbps fibre 
for R10k where as in america you can get Google Fibre for R 733.34 and 
thats 1gbps. Also the roll out is said to be going strong but I am yet to 
see the output of the telkom rollout, also i bet you telkom will keep the 
fibre lines to themselves for a few months at least. AT&T would never come 
here, i mean because of the latest riots stuff BMW pulled out of building a 
factory here, and that could have brought +- 5000 Jobs to our country.

+Paul Murdoch
what you're talking about is years beyond us,
We'd need an azure server, first of all, which works out a specific 
algorithm, and at the moment we fail to meet microsoft requirements for 
Azure servers cause we only have one power company (who, might i add, is 
the only company who tells people not to use their product)
we need a cctv system that runs at marginal IP cameras with 3-5 megapixels, 
which can identify licenseplates/faces/items in possession. and that's just 
step 1. By the time we can get something to do that, step 2 would probably 
be null and void ie it will probably happen in 2090 (at the rate of which 
our country is currently "progressing" )

and while we're on the subject-

Fibre, for example, will take more than 2 more years to integrate to ALL 
over south africa instead of just the main areas, if not more.
And if this wonderful country was filled with people who actually knew 
anything about business and realized that ICASA is a bunch of idiots, maybe 
we'd already have all the internet we ever needed fed to us directly from 
LEO satellites run by AT&T who wouldn't charge us such absolutely 
outrageous prices for a highly unstable ADSL line.

They do have patrols all around. Everywhere you look there is enforce. I 
stumble upon many cars at midnight even. But granted it was a short time 
frame to work with. We need a lot more of these cameras and not 5 central 
hubs but ONE central hub with a computer algorithym that identifies this 
type of thing.

Firstly this shouldn't be about race, because if the video is staged, then 
both racies involved are pathetic. Secondly the video does have a few 
discrepancies like the guns not visible. There are three men claimed to be 
suspects but if look carefully two other guys walking in the opposite 
direction are the ones who seem to run in the initial direction that the 
mother went. The video is longer than two and half minutes because the is a 
pause with a caption readinh "few minutes later, the mother walks back to 
the car" and suddenly there is a white car parked parallel to the vehicle 
concerned. When it came or how long the video was shortened is unknown. 
Then theres the lady who drives off with the other vehicle. However if this 
is true, Enforce should've responded within 3mins atleast and it's
